questions.question: What is machine learning?
options: A field of computer science focused on building physical robots
A discipline of mathematics focused on pure algebraic structures
A subset of AI that enables systems to learn from data without being explicitly programmed
A methodology for database management and indexing
questions.answer: A subset of AI that enables systems to learn from data without being explicitly programmed
questions.explanation: Machine learning is a subset of AI where models learn patterns from data rather than being explicitly coded with rules.

questions.question: Which of the following is a type of machine learning?
options: Supervised Learning
Interpreted Learning
Translated Learning
Conceptual Learning
questions.answer: Supervised Learning
questions.explanation: Supervised learning uses labeled data to train models.

questions.question: What differentiates supervised from unsupervised learning?
options: Supervised uses labeled data, while unsupervised uses unlabeled data
Supervised uses unlabeled data, while unsupervised uses labeled data
Both use only unlabeled data
There is no difference
questions.answer: Supervised uses labeled data, while unsupervised uses unlabeled data
questions.explanation: In supervised learning, the model learns from labeled examples. In unsupervised learning, the model uncovers patterns from unlabeled data.

questions.question: Which of the following is a supervised learning task?
options: Clustering customers by their purchasing behavior
Finding topics in a set of unlabeled documents
Predicting house prices based on historical labeled data
Detecting anomalies without any labeled examples
questions.answer: Predicting house prices based on historical labeled data
questions.explanation: Predicting house prices is a regression task with known target values, making it a supervised learning problem.

questions.question: What is a 'feature' in machine learning?
options: A parameter of the learning algorithm
An individual measurable property of the data
A synonym for the model’s output
A step in data preprocessing
questions.answer: An individual measurable property of the data
questions.explanation: Features are input variables used by the model to make predictions.

questions.question: Which algorithm is commonly used for classification tasks?
options: Linear Regression
Support Vector Machine (SVM)
K-Means Clustering
Principal Component Analysis
questions.answer: Support Vector Machine (SVM)
questions.explanation: SVM is often used for classification due to its ability to find optimal separating hyperplanes.

questions.question: What is overfitting in machine learning?
options: When a model performs poorly on both training and test sets
When a model fits the training data too closely and fails to generalize
When a model cannot fit the training data at all
When a model has fewer parameters than necessary
questions.answer: When a model fits the training data too closely and fails to generalize
questions.explanation: Overfitting occurs when a model learns noise and details specific to the training data, harming its performance on new data.

questions.question: Which technique can help prevent overfitting?
options: Using a larger model
Reducing the training data size
Implementing regularization (e.g., L2, dropout)
Not splitting data into train and test sets
questions.answer: Implementing regularization (e.g., L2, dropout)
questions.explanation: Regularization techniques help the model generalize better by penalizing complex models.

questions.question: What is a 'neural network'?
options: A statistical method for hypothesis testing
A set of digital circuits performing logic operations
A computational model inspired by the structure of the brain’s neurons
A set of if-else rules
questions.answer: A computational model inspired by the structure of the brain’s neurons
questions.explanation: Neural networks are composed of layers of interconnected nodes (neurons) that learn complex patterns.

questions.question: What is reinforcement learning?
options: A type of supervised learning with labeled data
An approach where an agent learns by interacting with an environment and maximizing rewards
A form of unsupervised learning that clusters data
A method of data preprocessing
questions.answer: An approach where an agent learns by interacting with an environment and maximizing rewards
questions.explanation: Reinforcement learning involves an agent making decisions, receiving rewards, and improving its policy over time.

questions.question: Which metric is commonly used to evaluate classification performance?
options: Mean Squared Error
Accuracy
R-squared
Silhouette Score
questions.answer: Accuracy
questions.explanation: Accuracy is the ratio of correctly predicted instances to total instances, commonly used for classification evaluation.

questions.question: Which of the following is a regression task?
options: Identifying if an email is spam or not
Predicting tomorrow’s temperature in degrees Celsius
Classifying images as cat or dog
Clustering customers into groups
questions.answer: Predicting tomorrow’s temperature in degrees Celsius
questions.explanation: Regression involves predicting continuous values, such as temperature.

questions.question: How does logistic regression differ from linear regression?
options: Logistic regression predicts continuous values, while linear regression predicts probabilities
Logistic regression predicts categorical outcomes, while linear regression predicts continuous values
They are identical models
Linear regression is for classification and logistic regression is for regression
questions.answer: Logistic regression predicts categorical outcomes, while linear regression predicts continuous values
questions.explanation: Logistic regression outputs probabilities for classification, whereas linear regression outputs continuous values.

questions.question: What is gradient descent?
options: A method for measuring the performance of a model
An algorithm that adjusts parameters to minimize a cost function
A technique for dimensionality reduction
A method for feature selection
questions.answer: An algorithm that adjusts parameters to minimize a cost function
questions.explanation: Gradient descent updates model parameters in the direction that reduces the cost function.

questions.question: What is a confusion matrix?
options: A matrix used in dimensionality reduction
A table that shows the frequency of predictions versus actual classes
A method for training neural networks
A feature engineering technique
questions.answer: A table that shows the frequency of predictions versus actual classes
questions.explanation: A confusion matrix summarizes classification results by showing the counts of correct and incorrect predictions.

questions.question: What is cross-validation?
options: A method to visualize a model’s decisions
A technique to reduce overfitting by splitting data into multiple train/test subsets
A method for creating more complex models
A data cleaning process
questions.answer: A technique to reduce overfitting by splitting data into multiple train/test subsets
questions.explanation: Cross-validation improves generalization estimates by using multiple train/validation splits.

questions.question: In training neural networks, what's the difference between an epoch, a batch, and an iteration?
options: They are all the same thing
Epoch: one full pass over the dataset, Batch: a subset of data, Iteration: one update step
Epoch: a subset of data, Batch: one full pass, Iteration: a random sample
Iteration and batch are the same, epoch is different
questions.answer: Epoch: one full pass over the dataset, Batch: a subset of data, Iteration: one update step
questions.explanation: An epoch is a complete pass through the training set, a batch is a subset of the data, and an iteration is a single parameter update.

questions.question: How does a validation set differ from a test set?
options: They do not differ; both are the same
A validation set is used to tune hyperparameters, while a test set is used to evaluate the final model
A test set is used for tuning hyperparameters, while a validation set is the final evaluation
Both are used only for training
questions.answer: A validation set is used to tune hyperparameters, while a test set is used to evaluate the final model
questions.explanation: A validation set guides model selection and tuning, and the test set is for final performance measurement.

questions.question: What is the difference between a parameter and a hyperparameter?
options: Parameters are set by the model during training; hyperparameters are set by the user before training
Parameters are always integers; hyperparameters are floats
Hyperparameters are learned during training; parameters are fixed
They are synonymous
questions.answer: Parameters are set by the model during training; hyperparameters are set by the user before training
questions.explanation: Model parameters are learned from data, while hyperparameters are predefined settings chosen by the user.

questions.question: What is ensemble learning?
options: Using a single model to solve all problems
Combining multiple models to improve performance
A technique to visualize data
A method for regularization
questions.answer: Combining multiple models to improve performance
questions.explanation: Ensemble methods aggregate predictions from multiple models to reduce variance and improve accuracy.

questions.question: What is a Random Forest?
options: A single decision tree
An ensemble of decision trees trained on random subsets of data and features
A method for dimensionality reduction
A clustering algorithm
questions.answer: An ensemble of decision trees trained on random subsets of data and features
questions.explanation: Random Forests are ensembles of decision trees that improve generalization by averaging multiple trees.

questions.question: What is boosting?
options: A method for scaling features
A technique for data augmentation
An ensemble technique that trains models sequentially to correct the errors of previous models
A process for cleaning data
questions.answer: An ensemble technique that trains models sequentially to correct the errors of previous models
questions.explanation: Boosting builds strong models by iteratively learning from the mistakes of previous models.

questions.question: What is Gradient Boosting?
options: An unsupervised learning algorithm
A boosting method that uses gradients of the loss function to build new models
A way to perform gradient descent on the entire dataset
A clustering algorithm
questions.answer: A boosting method that uses gradients of the loss function to build new models
questions.explanation: Gradient Boosting builds new models that optimize the residual errors by following the gradient of the loss.

questions.question: What is Principal Component Analysis (PCA)?
options: A supervised learning algorithm
A method for feature extraction and dimensionality reduction
A clustering technique
A reinforcement learning algorithm
questions.answer: A method for feature extraction and dimensionality reduction
questions.explanation: PCA transforms data into a lower-dimensional space capturing the maximum variance.

questions.question: How does PCA differ from LDA (Linear Discriminant Analysis)?
options: PCA is supervised, LDA is unsupervised
PCA is unsupervised, LDA is supervised
Both are supervised methods
Both are unsupervised methods
questions.answer: PCA is unsupervised, LDA is supervised
questions.explanation: PCA focuses on variance in the data without labels, while LDA aims to maximize class separability using labels.

questions.question: How does reinforcement learning differ from supervised learning?
options: Reinforcement learning uses labeled data; supervised does not
Supervised learning has a reward signal; reinforcement does not
Reinforcement learning uses reward signals from environment interactions, supervised relies on labeled data
They are identical approaches
questions.answer: Reinforcement learning uses reward signals from environment interactions, supervised relies on labeled data
questions.explanation: RL agents learn from trial-and-error feedback, whereas supervised learning requires labeled examples.

questions.question: What is semi-supervised learning?
options: Learning from fully labeled datasets only
Learning without any labels at all
Learning from a combination of labeled and unlabeled data
A method for reinforcement learning
questions.answer: Learning from a combination of labeled and unlabeled data
questions.explanation: Semi-supervised learning leverages a small amount of labeled data and a large amount of unlabeled data.

questions.question: What is a ROC curve?
options: A plot of accuracy over training iterations
A graph showing the trade-off between true positive rate and false positive rate
A method for feature selection
A technique for dimensionality reduction
questions.answer: A graph showing the trade-off between true positive rate and false positive rate
questions.explanation: The ROC curve shows how sensitivity and specificity vary with different classification thresholds.

questions.question: What is AUC (Area Under the Curve)?
options: The integral of model loss over time
The area under the ROC curve, measuring classification quality
A dimension reduction technique
A parameter tuning method
questions.answer: The area under the ROC curve, measuring classification quality
questions.explanation: AUC summarizes the ROC curve into a single number representing the model’s ability to rank predictions.

questions.question: What is the difference between precision and recall?
options: Precision measures how many of the predicted positives are correct, recall measures how many of the actual positives are found
They are identical metrics
Recall measures false positives only, precision measures true positives only
Precision and recall both measure overall accuracy
questions.answer: Precision measures how many of the predicted positives are correct, recall measures how many of the actual positives are found
questions.explanation: Precision = TP/(TP+FP), Recall = TP/(TP+FN). They address different aspects of classification performance.

questions.question: What is the F1-score?
options: A measure of regression error
The harmonic mean of precision and recall
A metric for unsupervised clustering
An acronym for 'First metric'
questions.answer: The harmonic mean of precision and recall
questions.explanation: F1-score balances precision and recall, making it useful when you want a single measure of performance.

questions.question: What is the K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) algorithm?
options: A supervised method that classifies based on the majority label of nearest data points
An unsupervised method for clustering
A reinforcement learning strategy
A technique for dimensionality reduction
questions.answer: A supervised method that classifies based on the majority label of nearest data points
questions.explanation: KNN predicts the label of a new point by looking at the labels of its k closest neighbors.

questions.question: What is a decision tree?
options: A linear model for regression
A tree-structured model that splits data by features to make predictions
A clustering method
A neural network architecture
questions.answer: A tree-structured model that splits data by features to make predictions
questions.explanation: Decision trees iteratively split data into branches based on feature values, leading to a prediction at the leaves.

questions.question: What is Gini impurity?
options: A metric to measure how disorganized a dataset is in decision trees
A parameter in neural networks
A measure of linear correlation
A technique for dimensionality reduction
questions.answer: A metric to measure how disorganized a dataset is in decision trees
questions.explanation: Gini impurity measures the probability of misclassifying a random instance if it were labeled according to the current split.

questions.question: What is regularization?
options: A process that simplifies models to prevent overfitting
A way to increase model complexity
A technique for data augmentation
A clustering algorithm
questions.answer: A process that simplifies models to prevent overfitting
questions.explanation: Regularization adds constraints or penalties on the model parameters to avoid overfitting.

questions.question: How does L1 regularization differ from L2 regularization?
options: L1 encourages sparse solutions by using absolute values, L2 uses squared terms
They are identical methods
L2 encourages sparse solutions, L1 does not
L1 and L2 are only applicable in clustering
questions.answer: L1 encourages sparse solutions by using absolute values, L2 uses squared terms
questions.explanation: L1 regularization (Lasso) encourages sparsity, while L2 (Ridge) shrinks parameters smoothly.

questions.question: What is dropout in neural networks?
options: A method to stop training early
A form of regularization that randomly ignores some neurons during training
A technique to remove outliers
A way to speed up gradient descent
questions.answer: A form of regularization that randomly ignores some neurons during training
questions.explanation: Dropout helps prevent overfitting by making the network less reliant on specific neurons.

questions.question: What is the main difference between CNNs (Convolutional Neural Networks) and RNNs (Recurrent Neural Networks)?
options: CNNs process sequential data, RNNs process grid-like data
RNNs process image data, CNNs process text data
CNNs are good for spatial data (e.g., images), RNNs are good for sequential data (e.g., time series)
They are identical architectures
questions.answer: CNNs are good for spatial data (e.g., images), RNNs are good for sequential data (e.g., time series)
questions.explanation: CNNs specialize in handling spatial structures (images), while RNNs handle temporal sequences (text, time-series).

questions.question: What is transfer learning?
options: Training a model from scratch on a large dataset
Using a pre-trained model and adapting it to a new, related task
An unsupervised learning technique
A reinforcement learning strategy
questions.answer: Using a pre-trained model and adapting it to a new, related task
questions.explanation: Transfer learning leverages knowledge from one task to improve learning in another, related task.

questions.question: How does underfitting differ from overfitting?
options: Underfitting: good training performance but poor generalization; Overfitting: poor training performance
Underfitting: poor training and test performance; Overfitting: good training performance but poor test performance
They are the same phenomenon
Underfitting only occurs in neural networks
questions.answer: Underfitting: poor training and test performance; Overfitting: good training performance but poor test performance
questions.explanation: Underfitting means the model doesn’t learn enough even on training data. Overfitting means it learns patterns that don’t generalize.

questions.question: What is data augmentation?
options: Adding more training data by artificially modifying existing samples
Removing noisy data
Splitting data into train and test sets
Normalizing feature scales
questions.answer: Adding more training data by artificially modifying existing samples
questions.explanation: Data augmentation artificially increases the diversity of the dataset to improve model generalization.

questions.question: What is a generative model?
options: A model that discriminates between classes
A model that learns the joint probability of features and labels and can generate new samples
A method for dimensionality reduction
A reinforcement learning agent
questions.answer: A model that learns the joint probability of features and labels and can generate new samples
questions.explanation: Generative models learn the underlying distribution of data, allowing them to produce new, similar examples.

questions.question: Which of these is an unsupervised clustering technique?
options: Logistic Regression
K-Means
Random Forest
Gradient Boosting
questions.answer: K-Means
questions.explanation: K-Means is a classic unsupervised algorithm for partitioning data into K clusters.

questions.question: How does hierarchical clustering differ from K-Means?
options: Hierarchical clustering requires specifying the number of clusters in advance, K-Means does not
K-Means builds a hierarchy of clusters, hierarchical clustering does not
Hierarchical clustering builds a hierarchy of clusters, K-Means does not
They are identical methods
questions.answer: Hierarchical clustering builds a hierarchy of clusters, K-Means does not
questions.explanation: Hierarchical clustering creates a cluster tree. K-Means partitions data into a fixed number of clusters.

questions.question: What is t-SNE used for?
options: Classification
Dimensionality reduction and visualization of high-dimensional data
Clustering with centroids
Hyperparameter tuning
questions.answer: Dimensionality reduction and visualization of high-dimensional data
questions.explanation: t-SNE is a technique that projects high-dimensional data into a lower-dimensional space for visualization.

questions.question: What is the difference between model-based and instance-based learning?
options: Model-based learning uses a general model from training data; instance-based learning memorizes the training instances
They are identical
Instance-based learning creates a general model, while model-based memorizes instances
Model-based learning relies on external databases, instance-based does not
questions.answer: Model-based learning uses a general model from training data; instance-based learning memorizes the training instances
questions.explanation: Model-based approaches derive a model summarizing the data, while instance-based approaches rely on specific instances.

questions.question: What is a Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM)?
options: A supervised learning model for classification
An unsupervised model that assumes data is generated from a mixture of Gaussian distributions
A linear regression method
A reinforcement learning policy
questions.answer: An unsupervised model that assumes data is generated from a mixture of Gaussian distributions
questions.explanation: GMMs represent data as a mixture of multiple Gaussian distributions, suitable for clustering and density estimation.

questions.question: What are word embeddings?
options: Random strings used as inputs to text models
Fixed representations of words as dense vectors capturing semantic meaning
A type of dimensionality reduction only for images
Hard-coded rules for NLP
questions.answer: Fixed representations of words as dense vectors capturing semantic meaning
questions.explanation: Word embeddings map words to high-dimensional vectors that capture semantic relationships.

questions.question: What is a language model?
options: A model that generates natural language or predicts the next word
A model that classifies images
A model that only works on numeric data
A reinforcement learning policy
questions.answer: A model that generates natural language or predicts the next word
questions.explanation: Language models predict the probability of word sequences, enabling tasks like text generation.

questions.question: What is a Transformer in the context of deep learning?
options: A convolution-based model for images
A neural network architecture that uses self-attention to handle sequences
A reinforcement learning algorithm
A simple linear model for regression
questions.answer: A neural network architecture that uses self-attention to handle sequences
questions.explanation: Transformers rely on self-attention mechanisms, making them well-suited for processing sequences without recurrent structures.
